history.content:
I say take the internship. A few reasons. One, you are not behind at all if you take cs 70 in the fall, you're right on schedule! You can still do 188 with 70 in the fall, and then 170 and another cs class in the spring (61c maybe)? Two, even though this internship isn't software engineering, it's data science which involves a lot of programming, and a really productive way to spend your summer. Three, if your getting paid, you're making money vs spending money. Four, you get to be home with friends and family! Five, I've heard its way easier to get an internship once you've had an internship, so you'd have a much easier time finding something more software engineering for your next summer. To me, it's a pretty clear choice. 

__________________________________________________________________________

A different opinion: the internship sounds like grunt work. realistically, with just 61A/B under your belt, you won't be doing anything but very basic scripting to go through conversations, most of which you'd actually end up looking through manually to uncover 'patterns and insights'. The real NLP/analysis stuff is most likely out of your grasp; unless you are amazing at self-learning, you will likely get little to no guidance at a startup like this. take cs70. You're a freshman; this internship will not be a jumping off point for future SWE/tech internships, given that it's data analysis. Having a freshman and sophomore internship in my case (at a very well known company) did little to help me in my junior year compared to my friends who took courses and focused on academics. Additionally, having more classes like 170 under your belt will help you in your future internships far more. Also, 70 in the summer is fabulous - you really get time to focus on it and absorb it.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This is the most surprising post I've ever seen. The fact that the OP feels like he needs to even consider this means that these "prerequisite" rules are incentivizing inefficiency. The obvious choice here is the internship. Employers and heck, even professors would consider this data science experience for a freshman as pretty impressive, and would lead to interesting opportunities in the future. Industry has a strong preference for work experience - nobody cares at the career fair if you've take a CS 70 discrete math course. They probably even don't really care if you've taken 170/188 that much, given that there are 1000000 similar CS resumes that say "CS 70 188 170 162...". Think about this too - even if you did CS 70, that shouldn't take up your entire summer; what other productive things can you be doing on the side time? If it's some meaningful research then this balances it out, but for now, the choice is clear.

children.subject: Ah you're right in the sense that cs70 is a prerequisite http://ai.berkeley.edu/course_policies.html but it seems like you could self study probability before hand.
Also note that 188 only really uses discrete probability (and not a lot of it at that) in the middle-ish portion of the class, so it's perfectly OK to take it concurrently with 70.

I guess that’s true. Although I think CS70 is a prerequisite for 188 no? Also, there’s some other stuff I could do I didn’t mention if that changes anything. I could TA for CS61B, and I also have a long term project I want to work on. But then again, I guess you’re right that having past experience might triumph no matter what.

Is that a common thing? That would definitely be an option.

Although any idea if the really legit internships want algorithms?

ima keep it real with you, but the internship sounds like grunt work. realistically, with just 61A/B under your belt, you won't be doing anything but very basic scripting to go through conversations, most of which you'd actually end up looking through manually to uncover 'patterns and insights'. take cs70. You're a freshman; this internship will not be a jumping off point for future SWE/tech internships, given that it's data analysis, and having more classes like 170 under your belt will help you in your future internships far more. Also, 70 in the summer is fabulous - you really get time to focus on it and absorb it.

Internship sounds like complete grunt work, the sort of thing that people joke about as 'being MTurk' (referring to AWS Mechanical Turk) but if you would do it purely for your resume that's fine. Realistically you would not get much out of it.

The answers really vary, because it depends on what you get out of it (in terms of skills, and resume value, although I'd prioritise skills, resume value will sooner or later follow with a good skillset); if you can get some valuable experience, the internship is definitely worth it, but if you feel like the role won't give you much, doing 70 over the summer might benefit you in terms of opening up the door to upper division classes sooner.

You could talk to the company and ask them for more details/specifics beyond the description, that might help you decide.

This is all dependent on the actual content of the internship.

People who support the internship believe it is a 'data science' opportunity. If it genuinely is data science, and you will be doing stuff with NLP and statistics, then it will definitely put you ahead.

People who don't support the internship believe it will just be grunt work, and you will end up manually reading through lots of chat logs or collecting surface-level data. This obviously will be a waste of time.

It comes down to what you think you will be doing at the internship. Since it's a startup, I almost guarantee you that you will be receiving little guidance, so your experience will reflect mostly what you are capable of. If you do not know a lot about stats/ML/data science, then you will not be learning that stuff and will likely be limited to doing grunt work.

Clarify what you will be doing/what support you will be receiving with the startup. And by the way, did you need to do a coding or stats/data science interview at all? Did the company mention a specific technology stack or technical tools they would want you to use? If not, then the internship is almost guaranteed to be grunt work and not worth your time.
A lot of you are completely against one or the other option. Basically what I’m wondering is, will a freshman internship like this actually put me ahead?
Updated my post to make some clarifications. CS70 is not all I’d be doing over the summer. Thank you everyone though! These are really helping me.

I'll come from a different perspective - CS70 over the summer was one of the best decision I've made to be completely honest. I thoroughly enjoyed the material since I had more time to think about it (I had earlier enrolled for a few weeks in the Spring semester before the summer and dropped it at the drop deadline and hated the class). I also did academic interning for two classes during that summer as well - so if you have something significant you'd like to work on along with CS70, it's doable and I'd definitely recommend this option.

Personally, even my first internship interview focused on my side projects (I had a few) - so if you're scared of not having any experience for your next internship, I don't think it'll be that big of an issue if you've got other things you're working on during the summer. In terms of what I see in the job description for your internship offer, I don't think it's the most technical experience - strong research and/or side projects that are presentable, in my opinion, could make the same difference in terms of recruiting.

Good luck with your decision!

I did 61A and 61B (did one unit for each). I think I'd have had time to take on a more serious side project had I only academic interned for one class - but again it's important to remember that everyone works at separate paces.
Would you recommend doing both, or jut doing data structures?

Hey! Thank you so much for your response. If I may ask, what courses did you intern for? I’m considering CS61B, but I’d also be interested in doing 61A too. However I don’t wanna spread myself too thin since I wanna work on side projects as well.

history.content:
I received an offer for a summer internship at a company in NY (where I’m from), and I’m having a difficult time deciding whether or not I should take the internship or take CS70 over the summer. I know off the bat the internship sounds better, but from what it sounds, it’s not software engineering. So although it might look better on paper to have an internship, I’m not sure if taking 70 so that I could take 188 and 170 this fall is better. For some context, here’s how they described what I’d be doing:

“Duties: You will be working on data analysis on user behavior for our Kai product, including analyzing logs of conversations our AI bot has had with consumers, and finding patterns and insights in the data that would have direct effect on the Kasisto’s development roadmap.”

So basically, if you were in my shoes, what would you do and why?

Thank you so much for all the help everyone!


P.S. The company is called Kasisto if that helps. It’s an AI chat bo for financial helpt. Also, I’m a freshman, so offers aren’t exactly raining.

UPDATE: I forgot to mention that if I stayed, I’d be an academic intern for CS61B, and idk if I’d get it, but I’d do my best to get some research. I also have some side projects i want to work on.
history.subject: Summer Advice
